sentence: Following the screening process, 36 studies (from 41 publications reporting QoL outcomes in patients with FD) were included in the analysis (Fig. 1A; Table 1A).
Five studies evaluated the impact of FD on QoL in different patient populations using the EQ-5D descriptive system [35, 41, 45–47], and domain-specific findings are presented in Fig. 2A.
An overview of mean VAS scores is presented in Fig. 2B.

Among the studies comparing scores to a relevant normative population, all reported a significantly lower mean score in the patient population compared with controls (p ≤ 0.02 in all three studies).Impact of patients’ sex and ERT on EQ-5D VAS findings
Three studies evaluated EQ-5D VAS scores according to sex (Fig. 2B), each of which reported a numerically higher mean score in female patients than in male patients: 76.8 versus 72.6, 72 versus 65, and 75.8 versus 69.7 for females versus males across the three studies by Löhle, Żuraw, and Nowak, respectively, although none of these differences between sexes were statistically significant [33, 41, 48]. Żuraw and colleagues also analyzed the impact of ERT on EQ-5D VAS scores [41].

Following the screening process, 18 studies (from 19 publications) were included in the analysis; two studies (from three publications) reported economic evaluations, 11 (from 11 publications) reported cost burden and resource use, and seven (from seven publications) reported utility review (Fig. 1B; Table 1B).
Following the screening process, 36 studies (from 41 publications reporting QoL outcomes in patients with FD) were included in the analysis (Fig. 1A; Table 1A).
Five studies evaluated the impact of FD on QoL in different patient populations using the EQ-5D descriptive system [35, 41, 45–47], and domain-specific findings are presented in Fig. 2A.
An overview of mean VAS scores is presented in Fig. 2B.

Among the studies comparing scores to a relevant normative population, all reported a significantly lower mean score in the patient population compared with controls (p ≤ 0.02 in all three studies).Impact of patients’ sex and ERT on EQ-5D VAS findings

Żuraw and colleagues also analyzed the impact of ERT on EQ-5D VAS scores [41].

Following the screening process, 18 studies (from 19 publications) were included in the analysis; two studies (from three publications) reported economic evaluations, 11 (from 11 publications) reported cost burden and resource use, and seven (from seven publications) reported utility review (Fig. 1B; Table 1B).

Impact of patients’ sex and ERT on EQ-5D VAS findings
Three studies evaluated EQ-5D VAS scores according to sex (Fig. 2B), each of which reported a numerically higher mean score in female patients than in male patients: 76.8 versus 72.6, 72 versus 65, and 75.8 versus 69.7 for females versus males across the three studies by Löhle, Żuraw, and Nowak, respectively, although none of these differences between sexes were statistically significant [33, 41, 48]. Żuraw and colleagues also analyzed the impact of ERT on EQ-5D VAS scores [41].

Żuraw and colleagues also analyzed the impact of ERT on EQ-5D VAS scores [41].
